Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 1: Meghdoot: A Multi-Cloud Infrastructure for Enhancing Sustainability via Effective Monitoring of Inland Waters and Coastal Wetlands

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of the project is the design and prototype implementation of a multi-cloud computing framework that seamlessly integrates community observations, remote sensing measurements, and advanced multimedia analytics for effective environmental monitoring. This infrastructure, called Meghdoot, will be employed for early detection of salt marsh stress in coastal areas and cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms in inland waters. This framework will harness multiple clouds including community clouds, sensor clouds, and computational clouds to develop efficient and timely event detection strategies. In addition, efficacious mechanisms for motivating and enabling community members to contribute high-quality content for enhanced environmental monitoring will be investigated. The first research thrust of the proposed project is to invent mechanisms to effectively leverage community clouds for monitoring lakes and salt marshes. In this community-as-sensors paradigm, data produced by individuals of the community (i.e., blogs, images, tweets) in online social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, etc.) will be used to generate trustworthy, actionable information. This, in turn, will act as the initial trigger for activating the traditional sensing infrastructure. The data from sensor clouds comprised of high resolution cameras and hyperspectral radiometers will be processed through the computational cloud using specialized techniques such as segmentation, feature extraction, registration, indexing, and spectral models for producing estimates of the cyanobacteria concentration and marsh biophysical characteristics from the study sites. The final research thrust of this project will focus on the optimization of the deployment and operation of the sensor cloud based on the information from the community cloud and the results from the computational cloud.

This project addresses two environmental issues important to coastal states in southeastern United States, namely, harmful algal blooms and marsh browning events. Over the last decade the frequency and magnitude of these environmentally detrimental events have gone up primarily because of drought as well as sea level rise. Therefore, accurate, cost-effective, and targeted monitoring of these events is indispensable to sustainable management of the environment. The proposed cyber-infrastructure-based warning system will enable early detection and timely implementation of preemptive measures to reduce the frequency and severity of future events while ensuring environmental conservation and sustainability. The project plans to engage students, community leaders, resource managers, and the general public via training, workshops, and social media in various aspects of the research starting from crowd sourcing to environmental sensor deployments, data acquisition, processing, and interpretation. The success of the proposed project will pave the way for a state-wide automated early detection, warning and rapid response system that can be adopted by state-level environmental agencies to alert restoration officials and lay citizens of impending risks associated with these events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyanobacterial Harmful Algal Blooms (CyanoHABs), aka blue-green algae, are a major water quality and public health issue in inland waters such as lakes and ponds as they degrade aquatic habitats, can cause fish kills, hamper recreational activities, and potentially affect human health via toxic contamination. The two traditional approaches for monitoring CyanoHABs, namely in-situ monitoring and satellite-based remote sensing suffer from inherent limitations. While in-situ sampling is laborious and time-consuming, satellite-based remote sensing techniques are not very accurate.

The overall objective of this project was to design and develop a robust and scalable framework that integrates community observations (via social media and smartphone apps), remote sensing measurements, satellite data and advanced multimedia analytics for early detection of CyanoHABs. A number of research activities were carried out as a part of this project.

We conducted a comprehensive study of social media activity on CyanoHABs. More than 120,000 microblogs (tweets) containing CyanoHABs-related keywords such as cyanobacteria, algae bloom, blue green algae were collected. We conducted an empirical study on the effectiveness and reliability of various keywords for CyanoHABs activity monitoring. One of the key findings of our study was that CyanoHABs-related content on social media exhibits significant degree of concept drift, which adversely impacts machine learning algorithms and periodic retraining of even small amounts of data can alleviate the negative impact of concept drift. This project also resulted in a novel technique for scalably labeling large corpora of tweets for using them as training sets. A machine-learning and natural language processing-based pipeline was designed and implemented for extracting location and date information from tweets and news articles. In addition, user-friendly smartphone apps called CyanoTracker was designed, implemented (on iOS and Android), and released to enable citizen scientists and other stakeholder communities to easily and accurately report CyanoHAB events.

Cost-effective solar-energy driven  hyperspectral wireless sensor setups for continual monitoring of CyanoHABs in water bodies were built and deployed. These sensor setups periodically take hyperspectral reflectance readings and upload them via the mobile network. They were instrumental in collecting CyanoHAB data from three locations in Georgia, namely, Lake Oglethorpe, Lake Chapman and Lake Oconee during summer of 2017, 2018 and 2019. Our work demonstrated that well designed hyperspectral sensor setup provides an effective and low-overhead  mechanism for monitoring water quality.

This project also addressed the problem of automated detection of CyanoHABs via analysis of image data of inland water bodies acquired using smartphones and tablet computers and communicated via social media platforms. To account for the wide variations in imaging parameters and ambient environmental parameters a deep learning-based techniques for image feature extraction and CyanoHABs identification were designed and implemented. As an extension of the above techniques, we designed an end-to-end trainable convolutional neural network that is capable of learning jointly from more than one image modality (e.g., satellite images and RGB images).

A Google Earth Engine-based quick analysis tool that incorporates location information extracted from news feeds and integrates it with remote sensing models was developed to quantify CyanoHABs and produce satellite data derived spatial maps to isolate bloom areas. This tool enables quick, large-scale monitoring of CyanoHABs. The results produced through this tool were regularly posted to the project website.

Our team provided satellite maps to NASA Landsat Science Team. We also provided 2019 Lake Erie CyanoHABs map to Booth Michigan to produce news article that was shared 40K times. Important and timely information about CyanoHABs was continuously disseminated through our Twitter handle (@CyanoTracker) and our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/cyanotracker). Our Twitter handle has more than 1800 followers. These include NASA, ESA, NOAA, USGS Landsat Program, Utah Health Department and many private sector companies.

The research conducted in this project has generated 14 peer-reviewed conference and journal publications, 12 conference presentations, 2 mobile apps and 6 wireless hyperspectral sensor kits. In addition, the cyberinfrastructure developed in this project is reproducible and scalable to any geographic region. 

As a part of outreach activities, a workshop on CyanoHABs and water quality was conducted in North Oconee High School (NOHS) on 09/21/2016. 52 high school students from AP environmental science and computer science courses participated in the workshop.

Many aspects of this project were incorporated into several courses taught by the PIs at UGA. Towards broadening participation, PIs placed special emphasis on encouraging female students to participate in the project. As a result, of the 12 graduate students (4 PhD and 8 Masters) students that conducted their dissertation research on topics pertaining to this project, 6 were women.

 In terms of broader impact, this project produced techniques and infrastructures for early detection of CyanoHABs in waterbodies. In doing so, this project has laid the foundation to enable timely interventions to ameliorate the severity of CyanoHABs and restoration of waterbodies. Our outreach activities have created public awareness about this important water resources sustainability issue.
